frontmatter.author: Toby Bridle
frontmatter.title: How I created A Blog Page using Gatsby & React
frontmatter.description: My (annoying) journey using Gatsby, React & Recoil

markdownRemark.html:
The Initial Idea

I knew I needed some (more) projects to add to my portfolio, since the existing ones were not showcasing my skills. I needed something that, though giving me more experience & confidence in React, would not consume all of my freetime (it was the Christmas holidays - time for relaxing). I went through my Figma and found a design for a college project (BHASVIC Magazine) that I hadn't ended up using. It matched my criteria, and was easy enough to code.

A Timeline of Development

Though this project was not too time consuming, I still had quite a few hiccups. For the first few hours, development was going swimmingly. The theme switching was working - and the components such as the Navbar and PageMeta were coming along nicely; however, I encountered a problem that I had overlooked: hosting. At the time, I was using create-react-app to bundle my code. It did not provide the features that I needed. This is when I looked to Gatsby. I ported all of my Components from my create-react-app project over to Gatsby - also switching from Redux to Recoil. I found Recoil much simpler to use, and it turns out it's also much faster (O(1) rather than O(n)`).
